conclusion: Calculate the work done by the frictional force on the object as it moves from point M to point N.
The object is initially at rest on the conveyor belt, and the frictional force is given by the coefficient of kinetic friction μ.
Identify the initial and final positions of the object. The object starts at point M and moves to point N.
Calculate the initial velocity of the object using the formula: v_i = v × sin(θ) where v = 6 m/s and θ = π/2.
Calculate the final velocity of the object using the formula: v_f = v × cos(θ) where v = 6 m/s and θ = π/2.
Calculate the distance traveled by the object: d = v × t = 6 × t.
Calculate the work done by the frictional force: W = μmg × d where μ = 0.3, m = 3 kg, and g = 10 m/s².
Substitute the values into the work formula: W = 0.3 × 3 × 6 × 10.
Calculate the work done: W = 36 J.
Since the object starts from rest, the work done by friction is equal to the change in kinetic energy of the object.
The change in kinetic energy is: ΔK = 1/2 m v² - 1/2 m v_i².
Calculate the final kinetic energy: ΔK = 36 J.
Since the work done by friction is equal to the change in kinetic energy, the work done by the frictional force is: W = ΔK = 36 J.
Verify the calculations to ensure they match the given values.
The work done by the frictional force is 36 J.
